channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-9045] Support Dictionary based Tag compression in HFiles
item.description: Along with the DataBlockEncoding algorithms, Dictionary based Tag compression can be done
item.summary: Support Dictionary based Tag compression in HFiles

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
-1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12610802/HBASE-9045.patch
against trunk revision .

+1 @author. The patch does not contain any @author tags.

+1 tests included. The patch appears to include 3 new or modified tests.

+1 hadoop1.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 1.0 profile.

+1 hadoop2.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 2.0 profile.

-1 javadoc. The javadoc tool appears to have generated 7 warning messages.

+1 javac. The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

-1 findbugs. The patch appears to introduce 3 new Findbugs (version 1.3.9) warnings.

+1 release audit. The applied patch does not increase the total number of release audit warnings.

+1 lineLengths. The patch does not introduce lines longer than 100

-1 site. The patch appears to cause mvn site goal to fail.

-1 core tests. The patch failed these unit tests:
org.apache.hadoop.hbase.io.encoding.TestEncodedSeekers

Test results: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/7663//testReport/

This message is automatically generated.

Patch looks good.

Consider a unit test that checks tag compression as part of reading and writing a HFile V3. Currently there's only low level test coverage for the tag compression context. Could be useful to check if it works with some legitimate combinations of HFile encoding options.

Thanks Andy for your review.
Corrected test failure.
I can not see any new findbugs / javadoc warnings from this patch.
Added tests which cover read/write HFile with/without tag compression
By default tag compression is ON for a CF so existing test cases were covering the tag compression/uncompress logic. New test changes covers tag compression OFF also

Thanks for the test addition.

Pardon if I missed this earlier. It's a bit strange that tag compression is toggled on and off by a family attribute. But I guess so is the data block encoding.

This message is automatically generated.
Checking the findbugs report, I can not see any warnings from the code this patch touches. Seems unrelated.
+1 on patch v2
Thanks Andy. Will commit tomorrow morning IST unless objections

Sorry for being late into this,
Just thinking on this do we always need to compress tag by tag or sometimes the entire tag part can be compressed. In some cases compressing the entire thing would be simple and would be better for that scneario I feel. That would imapct the WAL compresssion also then. Can do it based on configuration?
We are having two flavours of compress and uncompress tags. I can get the meaning when combined with the WAL tag compression. 


Context that holds the dictionary for Tag compression and doing the compress/uncompress. This

 * will be used for compressing tags while writing into WALs.

Can change this javadoc in TagCompressionContext.
In what scenario can a byte buffer be not backed by an array? 


if (in.hasArray())

Is it because in some cases we are passing just an empty bytebuffer? Looks good overall.

Can do it based on configuration?

IMO deciding such a conf is hard. Tags might be internally used for different use cases later. (Already there are some plans in other jiras) For a user to know all these and deciding such a conf will be hard right? That is why I am thinking that tag by tag compression will be safe. What do you say?

Will correct the javadoc. I missed that in this patch. Thanks for the finding.

if (in.hasArray())

That is the recommendation from javadoc for using array()

Invoke the hasArray method before invoking this
method in order to ensure that this buffer has an accessible backing
array.

do we always need to compress tag by tag or sometimes the entire tag part can be compressed. In some cases compressing the entire thing would be simple and would be better for that scneario I feel. That would imapct the WAL compresssion also then.

Interesting point. For the case where there's just one tag on the cell, it's the same, and for cases where there are a number of cells with the exact same set of tags it would perform better. On the other hand, if cells have many common tags but the similarities don't coincide on any given cell then the dictionary will be inefficiently constructed compared to the per-tag approach. Probably the per-tag approach is better for the general case.

This patch adds a method 'shouldCompressTags' that looks like it should have been named 'isCompressTags' or 'getCompressTags'. If so, I'll open new issue to fix. Anoop Sam John

stack shouldCompressTags() went in to HColumnDescriptor. (No other places) All the existing boolean getters in HCD are named like shouldXXX() and I think I have gone with that same way at that time. As it is in a public client class, we can change now? 98.0 gone with this. Sorry abt that..

Sorry abt that..

No need to apologize. You did the right thing if the other members are named so. Let me file issue to deprecate 'should'. Thanks.

This issue was closed as part of a bulk closing operation on 2015-11-20. All issues that have been resolved and where all fixVersions have been released have been closed (following discussions on the mailing list).

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: When DataBlockEncoding is been used, tags also will be compressed using Dictionary. This can be disabled at a CF level using HColumnDescriptor#setCompressTags(boolean compressTags)
